title: 105_hr1461
content: The Act may be cited as the "Depository Institutions Disaster Relief Act of 1997". It pertains to the Truth in Lending Act and the Expedited Funds Availability Act. During the 240-day period after the enactment of the Depository Institutions Disaster Relief Act of 1997, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System can grant exceptions to the Truth in Lending Act and the Expedited Funds Availability Act for areas affected by major disasters, if it alleviates public hardships outweighing potential adverse effects. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may grant exceptions to the Expedited Funds Availability Act for depository institution offices in disaster-affected areas to alleviate public hardships, with exceptions expiring by September 1, 1998. The Board must publish statements in the Federal Register describing and justifying these exceptions. SEC. 3. DEPOSIT OF INSURANCE PROCEEDS. The Federal banking agency may allow an insured depository institution to deduct a qualifying amount of insurance proceeds from its total assets for leverage limit compliance if it meets certain criteria related to disaster relief areas designated by the President. The Federal banking agency may permit an insured depository institution to deduct insurance proceeds from its total assets for leverage limit compliance if it meets specific criteria related to disaster relief areas designated by the President. The institution must meet requirements such as deriving more than 60 percent of its deposits from individuals in devastated areas, being adequately capitalized before the disaster, and having a plan to manage the increase in assets and deposits. Section 38 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act sets a time limit on exceptions, expiring by February 28, 1999. Definitions include terms like "appropriate federal banking agency," "insured depository institution," "leverage limit," and "qualifying amount attributable to insurance proceeds." The term "proceeds" refers to the excess amount of an institution's total assets over its average total assets due to insurance payments or governmental assistance for damage or costs from a major disaster. SEC. 4. BANKING AGENCY PUBLICATION REQUIREMENTS. A qualifying regulatory agency can take actions regarding depository institutions or regulated entities in areas affected by a major disaster to facilitate recovery without complying with certain legal requirements. A qualifying regulatory agency can take actions without certain legal requirements in areas affected by a major disaster. The agency must publish a statement in the Federal Register describing and explaining the action taken. Qualifying regulatory agencies, including the Federal Reserve and the Treasury Secretary, can take actions without certain legal requirements in disaster-affected areas. Any exceptions made under this section expire by February 28, 1998. The Congress urges regulatory agencies to support financial institutions in assisting communities affected by the 1997 Red River flooding. This Act does not limit the authority of any other government department or agency.
